text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

(1) On December 1, 2008, the IRS initiated a two-year pilot Fast Track Settlement program for TE/GE taxpayers. On September 4, 2012, the program was extended indefinitely. This IRM section contains guidance for Appeals employees involved in the TE/GE Fast Track Settlement program.
Table of
Track Settlement (FTS) for Tax-Exempt/Government (TE/GE) Taxpayers 8.26.7
Taxpayers

) A primary objective of the Service is to resolve tax controversies at the level without compromising the quality and integrity of its determinations. of native dispute resolution programs achieve this objective. (
) The IRS Restructuring and Reform Act of
(RRA
the IRS to implement procedures to allow a broader use of early Appeals programs and adopt alternative dispute resolution methods, such as and arbitration. (
) Announcement
C.B.
established TE/GE FTS as a year pilot program to expedite case resolution and expand the range of resolution options available to TE/GE taxpayers. Announcement
I.R.B.
established TE/GE FTS as a permanent program. (

) TE/GE FTS is a service offered by the IRS for the purpose of enabling taxpayers, TE/GE, and the Office of Appeals to work together in resolving disputed issues while the case is under the jurisdiction of TE/GE. (
) TE/GE and Appeals administer the TE/GE FTS process jointly. The program available to taxpayers nationwide. (
) TE/GE FTS can be used to resolve factual and legal issues. The process be initiated at any time after an issue has been fully developed, but before FTS issuance of a
-day letter (or its equivalent). (

) TE/GE FTS is premised on the basis that TE/GE and the taxpayer have exhausted existing issue resolution strategies within TE/GE, including the Group Manager’s conference, and now want to use an optional strategy to reach a settlement. (

) TE/GE FTS employs various alternative dispute resolution techniques to promote case or issue resolution. An FTS Appeals Official serves as a party. A TE/GE Appeals Officer trained in mediation or, in limited cases, a mediation-trained Appeals Team Case Leader serves as the neutral FTS Appeals Official. The FTS Appeals Official does not perform in a traditional Appeals role, but rather uses dispute resolution techniques to facilitate ment between the parties. (
) If TE/GE FTS is unsuccessful in reaching a resolution, a taxpayer is not precluded from requesting traditional Appeals consideration. See IRM Unresolved Issues after TE/GE FTS. (
) When needed to effect a settlement based on the hazards of litigation, FTS allows the parties to utilize Appeals settlement authority under Order
(formerly Delegation Order
) and Delegation Order
Delegation Order
). See IRM
, Delegation of Authorities for the Appeals Process; IRM
, Judicial Attitude Toward Settlement. (
) TE/GE FTS takes place while the case is still under the jurisdiction of Benefits (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) (
) The TE/GE FTS process is designed to be completed within
calendar of acceptance of the TE/GE FTS Application (Form
, Application for Track Settlement). (
) Some of the objectives and benefits of TE/GE FTS are: (cid:
) Resolve issues at the lowest level possible; (cid:
) Use Appeals settlement authority during the examination process; (cid:
) Reduce overall case cycle time; (cid:
) Reduce taxpayer burden; and (cid:
) Optimize the use of internal resources. (

) All participants of the FTS session actively contribute to the resolution of case. The FTS session generally includes the taxpayer and/or the Dispute authorized representative(s), the TE/GE representative(s), and the FTS Process Appeals Official. A taxpayer is not required to have a representative in order participate in TE/GE FTS. (
) At least one person with decision-making authority from both the taxpayer TE/GE must be present at the FTS session. (

) The taxpayer and TE/GE representative(s) participating in the FTS session should also include individuals with the information and expertise necessary assist the parties and the FTS Appeals Official during the settlement However, the FTS Appeals Official may ask the parties to limit the number participants at the FTS session to facilitate the process. (

) In the event the parties cannot reach a settlement through the use of mediation techniques, the FTS Appeals Official has delegated settlement authority and the ability to offer a settlement in both factual and legal Neither party is obligated to accept the settlement proposal offered by the Appeals Official. (
) Announcement
I.R.B.
constitutes a delegation by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue Service of settlement authority to Grade Authority
and
Appeals Officers assigned to be Appeals FTS Officials for TE/GE FTS cases. (
) The delegation of settlement authority provided under Announcement
I.R.B.

includes the responsibility for arriving at the final from the Government’s perspective, approving the final settlement in accor- dance with the delegated authority, and executing the appropriate closing documents. This authority may not be re-delegated. (
) The TE/GE Group Managers and the Appeals Team Managers will identify determine cases eligible for TE/GE FTS. Case (

) The process of identifying cases eligible for FTS generally begins with the TE/GE representative(s). If a case qualifies for FTS, the TE/GE representa- tive(s) will discuss the FTS option with the taxpayer and explain the and benefits of the program. (
) The taxpayer may also initiate the TE/GE FTS process at any time after an issue has been fully developed but before a
-day letter (or its equivalent) issued. See IRM
, Initiating TE/GE FTS. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Track Settlement (FTS) for Tax-Exempt/Government (TE/GE) Taxpayers 8.26.7

) TE/GE FTS may not be the appropriate dispute resolution process for all involving TE/GE taxpayers. The TE/GE Group Manager and the taxpayer evaluate the individual circumstances of the case to determine if the FTS process meets their needs. (

) Generally, TE/GE FTS is available for non-docketed cases involving tax; exclusion of income from interest paid on municipal obligations; ment tax; estate and gift taxes; excise tax; exemption, foundation or for TE/GE qualification issues; or other such TE/GE functional issues as appropriate when: (cid:
) Issues are fully developed; (cid:
) The taxpayer has stated a position in writing; (cid:
) TE/GE and the taxpayer have exhausted available issue resolution gies including the Group Manager’s conference; and (cid:
) There are a limited number of unagreed issues. (
) If an issue is determined not to be eligible for TE/GE FTS, all issues the case are not eligible for TE/GE FTS. (

) The following cases are not eligible for TE/GE FTS: a. Issues that are eligible for other established settlement initiatives, such from but not limited to, the Self Correction Program, the Audit Closing Agreement Program, or other programs described in Rev. Proc.
I.R.B.

; b. Correspondence examination or determination cases; c. Cases in which the taxpayer has failed to respond to IRS or no documentation has been previously submitted for consideration TE/GE; d. Cases in which Appeals does not have jurisdiction (including of penalties under IRC
); e. Cases involving Listed Transactions or Abusive Tax Avoidance tions defined in IRM

; f. Cases involving potential for civil or criminal fraud; g. Rebate claim cases; h. Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act (TEFRA) partnership cases; i. Issues designated for litigation; j. Issues under consideration for designation for litigation; k. Frivolous issues, such as, but not limited to, those identified in Notice
I.R.B.

, or any successor guidance; l. “Whipsaw” issues, i.e., issues for which resolution with respect to one party might result in inconsistent treatment in the absence of the tion of another party; or m. Issues that have been identified in a Chief Counsel Notice, or publication, as excluded from the TE/GE FTS process. (
) While either the taxpayer or TE/GE can initiate the FTS process, both must agree to participate in the program. FTS

) APS will accord FTS cases priority treatment. (

8.26 Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) Program
Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) (
) TE/GE or Appeals will discuss other dispute resolution opportunities with the taxpayer, including
-day letter procedures contained in Pub
, Your Rights as a Taxpayer, or Pub
, Your Appeal Rights and How To Prepare a Protest You Don’t Agree. (
) Examples of cases that might not qualify for TE/GE FTS include the a. Cases with numerous issues, whether simple or complex, which will require longer than
days to resolve; b. Cases where TE/GE or the taxpayer are unable to meet during the
time frame; or c. Cases presenting high profile or sensitive issues. (
) The decision not to accept a case into the TE/GE FTS program is not to administrative appeal or judicial review. (
) Within
business days of case assignment, the FTS Appeals Official will: a. send Letter
, FTS Acknowledgment Letter, to the taxpayer; and Session b. contact the taxpayer and TE/GE to start the FTS planning process. (

) The FTS Appeals Official will identify, determine and confirm the number, and role of the respective participants to the FTS session and ensure that at least one person with decision-making authority from both the taxpayer and TE/GE will be present at the session. (

) The FTS Appeals Official will schedule the FTS session at a date and agreeable to both parties. The FTS Appeals Official will consider holding the session at a location that has the least cost or impact to the Service, such the local Office of Appeals. (

) The FTS Appeals Official may ask either party for additional information in order to acquire a full understanding of the issues. The FTS Appeals Official will share any information received with the other party prior to the FTS session. (
) The FTS Appeals Official will send the parties a customized copy of Letter
, Fast Track Settlement Agenda Letter, to confirm the agenda for the session. (
) The FTS Appeals Official will use a Form

, Fast Track Session Report, assist in planning the TE/GE FTS session and to report on developments the TE/GE during the FTS session. The FTS Session Report will include a list of all approved for the FTS program, a description of the issues, the amounts in dispute, conference dates, a plan of action for the FTS session and other mation useful to the process as determined by the parties and the FTS Appeals Official. (
) The FTS Appeals Official will open and lead the FTS session. All parties are active participants with equal voices. (
) Prior to opening the FTS session, the FTS Appeals Official will establish ground rules. The FTS Appeals Official may modify the rules during the FTS session to adapt to changes in circumstances.
Within 5 business days of case assignment, the FTS Appeals Official will:
Settlement (FTS) for Tax-Exempt/Government Taxpayers

) The FTS Appeals Official will prepare and update an agenda to guide the munication, set the order of issue discussion, and pose questions to clarify issues. During the FTS session, the FTS Appeals Official will provide makers from both parties with copies of the agenda and the FTS session report. (

) During the course of the FTS session, the FTS Appeals Official will employ various alternative dispute resolution techniques to promote case or issue resolution. The FTS Appeals Official does not perform in a traditional role, but rather uses dispute resolution techniques to facilitate settlement between the parties. (

) The FTS session may include joint sessions with all parties and/or separate meetings, as appropriate. The FTS Appeals Official will use various and mediation techniques to meet the needs and circumstances of each ticular case. (

) Since it is expected that the taxpayer and TE/GE have raised all issues and presented all relevant documentation before the FTS Application package is submitted to Appeals, the FTS Appeals Official will generally consider only FTS those issues outlined in the FTS Session Report. (

) If the taxpayer and/or TE/GE present new information during the FTS that was not previously presented during the examination, the FTS Appeals Official will consider whether it is necessary to adjust the targeted date or terminate the FTS session until both parties have had adequate review and evaluate the new information. (

) When the parties cannot reach a resolution through mediation, the FTS Appeals Official may propose a settlement on factual and/or legal issues. Neither party is obligated to accept the settlement proposal offered by the Appeals Official. (
) If the settlement proposed by the FTS Appeals Official is accepted by and the taxpayer, TE/GE will close the case using agreed case closing dures on the basis of the Appeals settlement proposal. (
) If the TE/GE Group Manager or their designee rejects the settlement by the FTS Appeals Official, the TE/GE Territory Manager must concur with rejection in writing. (

) If the TE/GE Territory Manager accepts the settlement proposed by the FTS Appeals Official, TE/GE will close the case using agreed case closing dures on the basis of the Appeals settlement proposal. (

) If the TE/GE Territory Manager concurs with the rejection of the settlement proposed by the FTS Appeals Official, and no acceptable alternative is reached, TE/GE will decide how it will proceed with the case. (

) Any recommended settlement by the FTS Appeals Official is subject to the same procedures and published guidance that would be applicable if the in was being considered by Appeals at the time of the recommendation. (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Track Settlement (FTS) for Tax-Exempt/Government (TE/GE) Taxpayers 8.26.7
If the TE/GE Group Manager or their designee rejects the settlement proposed by the FTS Appeals Official, the TE/GE Territory Manager must concur with the
Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) (
) For all issues coordinated as either Industry Specialty Program (ISP) or Appeals Coordinated Issues (ACI), Appeals will follow the procedures in IRM
, Review and Concurrence Procedures. (

) Where ACI/ISP/Compliance Coordinated Issues (CCI) are subject to the and concurrence by the Appeals Domestic Technical Specialist (DTS), the will generally serve as a team member and participate in the FTS session the taxpayer and TE/GE. If, for whatever reason, the DTS does not in the FTS session, the settlement of an ACI/ISP/CCI case remains subject the review and concurrence of the DTS. (
) All TE/GE FTS cases require a Form
, Fast Track Session Report, on which the FTS Appeals Official will notate the issues, adjustment dollars in
Fast Track dispute, and the disposition of each issue. Report (

) At the end of the FTS session, the FTS Appeals Official will solicit the (or representative(s), if applicable) and TE/GE to sign the report. The FTS Appeals Official will then give all session participants a signed copy of the report. (
) If the parties reach a basis for settlement during the FTS session, the signatures on Form

, Fast Track Session Report, signifies the terms of the settlement for purposes of preparing computations and documents. However, the FTS Appeals Official will explain to the parties the settlement is not final until all necessary closing documents and/or are signed. (
) The Form
, Fast Track Session Report, is not a waiver of restrictions assessment; does not terminate consents to extend the statute of and does not start the running of any new statute of limitations. (
) The signature of an IRS Official on the Fast Track Session Report does not preclude the reopening of the case under Policy Statement
found in
) If, after the FTS session, any issue remains unresolved, the FTS Appeals Official will follow the case closing procedures outlined in IRM
, Issues after Closing Procedures for Terminated, Withdrawn, or Unresolved TE/GE FTS FTS Cases. (
) If the parties fail to resolve any issue in TE/GE FTS, the taxpayer retains the standard appeal rights outlined in Pub
, Your Appeal Rights and How Prepare a Protest If You Don’t Agree. (

) If the case returns to Appeals under standard procedures, the Appeals Manager will assign the case to an Appeals employee other than the who acted as FTS Appeals Official during the TE/GE FTS process. (
) Both parties retain the right to withdraw throughout the entire TE/GE FTS process. from TE/GE (
) A party wishing to withdraw should provide written notice to the FTS Official and the other party. (
) In the event of a withdrawal, the FTS Appeals Official will return the TE/GE Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

The signature of an IRS Official on the Fast Track Session Report does not preclude the reopening of the case under Policy Statement 4-3 found in IRM
In the event of a withdrawal, the FTS Appeals Official will return the TE/GE

FTS Package to TE/GE and follow the case closing procedures outlined in IRM 8.26.7.8.1, Closing Procedures for Terminated, Withdrawn, or Unresolved TE/GE FTS Cases.
Although Appeals does not receive an administrative file in a TE/GE FTS case, APS must take appropriate action to close the case off of ACDS.
TE/GE FTS cases that are terminated, withdrawn, or fully unresolved will be closed on ACDS and returned to TE/GE for appropriate action.

If the FTS Appeals Official Then resolves the issues using Appeals settlement authority FTS Appeals Official will secure and/or the settlement is based on the appropriate agreement hazards of litigation documents, such as Form 870- AD, Form 866, or Form 906. Note: On Joint Committee Cases, Appeals does not execute any closing agreement until the settle- ment is cleared by Joint Committee. In those cases, the FTS Appeals Official will prepare a Form 5402, Appeals Transmittal and Case Memo, which states, “This case may not be closed until Joint Committee approval is received. Upon receipt of the Joint Committee letter, Appeals will execute a closing agreement and the case may then proceed through TE/GE closing procedures.”
through TE/GE closing procedures.” (
) The FTS Appeals Official will route the original TE/GE FTS Closing Package TE/GE through the Appeals Team Manager. (
) The Appeals Team Manager will send a copy of the TE/GE FTS Closing Package to APS to close the case on ACDS. (
) The FTS Appeals Official will send a copy of the Form
, Fast Track Session Report, and Form
, Appeals Transmittal and Case Memo, to Tax Policy & Procedure TE/GE FTS Program Manager. (
) The TE/GE FTS process is confidential. Confidentiality extends to all parties and all oral and written communications prepared in connection with the TE/GE FTS process. (
) IRS employees involved in any way with the TE/GE FTS process are subject to the confidentiality and disclosure provisions of the Internal Revenue Code. (
) Pursuant to IRC

(c), the taxpayer must consent to the disclosure of the taxpayer’s returns and return information pertaining to the issues being ered in the TE/GE FTS process to those persons named as participants on Form
, Application for Fast Track Settlement. The taxpayer consents executing Form
, Application for Fast Track Settlement.
IRS employees involved in any way with the TE/GE FTS process are subject to the confidentiality and disclosure provisions of the Internal Revenue Code.
Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) (
) IRS employees, the taxpayer, and persons invited to participate by the IRS the taxpayer shall not voluntarily disclose information made available during the FTS session, except as provided under
U.S.C. Section
) The prohibition on ex parte communications between Appeals employees other Internal Revenue Service employees provided by Section
of the in TE/GE Internal Revenue Service Restructuring and Reform Act of

does not apply to the communications arising in the TE/GE FTS process because the FTS Appeals Official is not acting in the traditional settlement role and tion of the case remains with TE/GE. See Rev. Proc.

) On TE/GE FTS cases returned for traditional Appeals consideration, ex parte restrictions will apply to communications between Appeals employees and other IRS originating functions, but will not apply to intra-Appeals tions. Appeals management will take appropriate measures to ensure that these cases are handled fairly and impartially. (

) At the conclusion of the TE/GE FTS session, the FTS Appeals Official will provide a Customer Satisfaction Survey to the taxpayer. The FTS Appeals Official will explain that the survey is voluntary but strongly encourage its completion. Survey data is used to evaluate and improve the overall TE/GE FTS process. Return completed surveys to:
